titleStmt.title: Detection, quantitation and identification of enteroviruses from surface waters and sponge tissue from the Florida Keys using real-time RT-PCR

analytic.title: Detection, quantitation and identification of enteroviruses from surface waters and sponge tissue from the Florida Keys using real-time RT-PCR

biblStruct.note: Received 1 March 2001; received in revised form 1 October 2001; accepted 1 October 2001

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: A method was developed for the quantitative detection of pathogenic human enteroviruses from surface waters in the Florida Keys using Taqman (R) one-step Reverse transcription (RT)-PCR with the Model 7700 ABI Prism (R) Sequence Detection System. Viruses were directly extracted from unconcentrated grab samples of seawater, from seawater concentrated by vortex flow filtration using a 100 kD filter and from sponge tissue. Total RNA was extracted from the samples, purified and concentrated using spin-column chromatography. A 192-196 base pair portion of the 5 0 untranscribed region was amplified from these extracts. Enterovirus concentrations were estimated using real-time RT-PCR technology. Nine of 15 sample sites or 60% were positive for the presence of pathogenic human enteroviruses. Considering only near-shore sites, 69% were positive with viral concentrations ranging from 9.3 viruses/ml to 83 viruses/g of sponge tissue (uncorrected for extraction efficiency). Certain amplicons were selected for cloning and sequencing for identification. Three strains of waterborne enteroviruses were identified as Coxsackievirus A9, Coxsackievirus A16, and Poliovirus Sabin type 1. Time and cost efficiency of this one-step real-time RT-PCR methodology makes this an ideal technique to detect, quantitate and identify pathogenic enteroviruses in recreational waters.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Rapid population growth and associated coastal development have led to the release of nutrients and enteric human pathogens to surface waters of the Florida Keys [1,2]. The pristine waters surrounding the Keys are important not only as a popular tourist destination, but also as the site of the only coral barrier reef tract in the continental United States. Reports of heavy algal growth and episodes of coral bleaching [3,4] have prompted several studies of surface water quality [5][6][7]. These reports have provided evidence that increased nutrification of these waters brought about by anthropogenic processes have resulted in the deterioration of water quality and coral reef health [5][6][7].

Advanced wastewater treatment exists in a few locations in the Keys, such as Key West and Key Colony Beach [8]. There are approximately 25,000 septic tanks, 5-10,000 illegal cesspits, and 1207 aerobic treatment units in the Florida Keys [9,10]. Unfortunately, these onsite systems provide only minimal if any removal of pathogens and nutrients from wastewaters [8]. Additionally, there are many houseboats which discharge untreated wastewater into the surrounding waters [8].

Currently, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) utilizes both E. coli and Enterococci as indicators of water quality in marine and fresh waters. However, bacterial indicators are more readily removed by sewage treatment processes such as chlorination and UV radiation than viruses [11]. Research has shown that enteric viral pathogens may be present even in the absence of bacterial indicators [2]. Furthermore, the presence of bacterial indicators does not necessarily indicate wastewater contamination has occurred because fecal coliforms can survive and proliferate in tropical waters [2,12,13].

Enteroviruses cause an estimated 30 million infections in the US each year [14], and it has been shown that pathogenic enteric viruses can enter near-shore waters through inadequate sewage systems. Additionally, Paul et al. [7,15,16] have shown rapid movement of viral tracers from septic tanks and injection wells into coastal waters of the Florida Keys. A previous study of water quality in the Florida Keys [2] determined that 79% of 19 canal sites sampled were positive for enteroviruses.

The health risks of recreational use of coastal waters contaminated by human sewage are well documented [17][18][19]. Swimmers were twice as likely to experience ear, eye, gastrointestinal or respiratory infections than other beach visitors in a study on the health effects of swimming at polluted Sydney beaches [19]. Windsurfers were found to be at increased risk when surfing on polluted waters [17]. Because of the widespread occurrence of waterborne enteroviral infections it is necessary to have methods for the detection, quantitation and identification of these viruses.

Until recently, cell culture was considered the method of choice for viral detection in the environment. However, compared to PCR, cell culture techniques are more costly, time consuming and less sensitive [20,21]. A one-step reverse transcription (RT)-PCR method combining Taqman technology with the ABI PRISM 7700 Sequence Detection System has enabled rapid detection and quantitation of target organisms. We have adapted this technology for enteroviral detection and quantitation and have combined it with cloning and sequencing to identify enteroviral types in surface waters of the Florida Keys.

div.head: Study site description
div.p: Seawater was collected from 15 sites (Table 4) surrounding Key West and the Dry Tortugas ( from a sponge found in the Fort Jefferson moat between the fort and the visitor septic systems.

div.head: Sampling
div.p: Some surface water samples (see Table 4) were grab sampled in 2 l sterile bottles for bacterial indicators. Subsamples 5-12 ml were taken and frozen directly for future enteroviral RNA extraction. Twenty litre samples were collected in sterile carboys and concentrated using vortex flow filtration (100 kD filter) with a Membrex Benchmark System (Membrex Inc., Garfield, NJ, USA). Griffin [22] found vortex flow filtration to be comparable to filter elution for the recovery of viruses from seawater. Jiang et al. [23] found the recovery efficiency of vortex flow filtration using the Membrex Benchmark System with a 100 kD filter to be 72.8% for marine viruses. The sponge sample was collected by standing down current of the sponge while cutting off a 3.2 g section using sterile scissors. The sponge fragment was placed in a sterile 50 ml tube and transported on ice to the lab where it was macerated and brought up in 40 ml of seawater from the moat (Fort Jeff moat 8B, Table 4).

Samples were stored at À201C until analysis. Spincolumn chromatography (RNeasy Mini Kit; Qiagen, Santa Clarita, California) was used to purify and concentrate 100 ml aliquots of all samples to 50 ml. Ten microlitres of each purified 50 ml concentrate was used for RT-PCR (for cloning and sequencing) and Taqman (R) one-step RT-PCR (for quantitative PCR).

div.head: Taqman (R) one-step RT-PCR
div.p: RT and PCR were carried out in the same buffer mix (Taqman s one-step RT-PCR Master Mix Reagents Kit) following the manufacturer's instructions for volumes, temperatures and cycle times. Primer concentration was 600 nM and probe concentration was 250 nM. During the RT step the reverse primer was utilized for initial priming on the mRNA for synthesis of the first cDNA strands. Amplification of a 192 base region of the 5 0 untranscribed region (UTR) of the enteroviral genome with a panenterovirus primer set (Table 1) was detected with an internal probe labeled with a reporter dye FAM (6-carboxyfluorescein) at the 0 end and a quencher dye TAMRA (6-carboxy-N,N,N 0 ,N 0 -tetramethylrhodamine) at the 3 0 end. The region amplified in the one-step RT-PCR reaction was approximately the same as that amplified in the RT-PCR reaction. Primers were slightly modified (Table 1) to accommodate the internal labeled probe.

div.head: Standard curve
div.p: Two milliliters of a Poliovirus Sabin type 1 cell culture was lysed by vigorous shaking and extracellular DNA was digested with pancreatic DNAase I. Viral particles were purified using a glycerol step gradient [24], stained with SYBR Gold s and directly counted using epifluorescence microscopy [25]. The stock dilution contained 9.1 Â 10 3 viruses/ml. Ten microlitre of the stock was purified and brought up in 70 ml of water. Five dilutions ranging from 1.3 Â 10 3 to 1.3 Â 10 1 were then made using UV treated 0.02 filtered DI water to create an RNA standard curve. RT-PCR on all standards was performed in triplicate.

div.head: Real-time PCR analysis
div.p: The 7700 Sequence Detection System was used to quantitate initial template quantities. Two seawater samples from the Keys previously found to be negative for enteroviruses by PCR were seeded with known viral titers, amplified in triplicate and quantitated using the standard curve.

div.head: RT-PCR (for cloning and sequencing)
div.p: Enteroviral RNA was reverse transcribed using random hexamers supplied in the PE applied biosystems RT-PCR core kit (Foster City, CA). A 196 base region of the 5 0 UTR of the enteroviral genome was amplified with a panenterovirus primer set (Table 1). RT-PCR Table 1 Enterovirus primer sets and probe for RT-PCR and one-step RT-PCR profile and master mix were as previously published [26].

div.head: Cloning and sequencing
div.p: Directly following visualization of the PCR products on a 1.5% agarose gel, 20 ml of the amplicon was purified using a QIAquick PCR purification kit (Qiagen, Santa Clarita, California) and resuspended in 30 ml of water. Four microliters of the purified amplicon was then immediately used for cloning with PCR 2.1 vector following instructions in the TOPO TA cloning kit (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). Approximately, 2-6 white colonies were picked and cultured overnight in 2X yeasttryptone broth (YT) containing 50 mg/ml ampicillin and 50 mg/ml kanamycin. Plasmids were isolated using the Wizard s Plus Minipreps DNA purification system, eluted in 50 ml of water, quantified by absorbance and sequenced by the DNA Sequencing Core Laboratory, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL.

div.head: Sequence alignment and phylogenetic analysis
div.p: Nucleotide sequences were BLAST [27] searched and identified through similarity in Genbank. Alignments were made using the alignment program in Omiga 2.0 (Oxford Molecular Ltd., Madison, WI). Kimura's 2parameter distance was calculated using transitions and transversions and a neighbor-joining tree was built using the Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis program, (Mega2 beta build 3 [28]). The confidence of recon-structed clades was tested by bootstrapping [29] with 1000 replicates.

div.head: Results
div.p: A standard curve of viral concentration versus threshold cycle was generated using the microscopically counted Poliovirus particles (Fig. 2). A coefficient of determination (r 2 ) of 0.99 showed a good linear relationship between threshold cycle (C t ) and virus concentration (31-1300 particles). To determine the efficiency of our extraction and concentration protocol two water samples from the Keys were seeded with known amounts of poliovirus and quantitated using the real-time standard curve ( Table 2). The percent recovery ranged from 32% to 73% with an average of 53%.

A total of 15 surface water samples were collected in the Florida Keys and Dry Tortugas in August 1997 (Table 4). Sponge tissue was collected from a sponge found in the moat surrounding Fort Jefferson (Fig. 1C). cloning, sequencing and BLAST [27] searching in Genbank. All sequences had 98-100% identity.

A phylogenetic tree (Fig. 3, Table 3) constructed from an alignment of the 196 base pair fragment of the 5 0 untranslated region of the enteroviral genome revealed two major clades based on the 196 base pair sequence of the 5 0 UTR. The largest clade contained Coxsackie A16, the group B Coxsackieviruses, the Echoviruses and Enterovirus 71. The smaller clade was comprised of the Polioviruses, Coxsackievirus A21, Coxsackievirus A24 and Enterovirus 70. Coxsackievirus A21 and Enterovirus 71 appear as sister-group to the remainder of the Poliovirus/Coxsackievirus A clade.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: A previous study [2] found 79% of sites sampled in the canals of the Florida Keys to be positive for enteroviruses by RT-PCR thus indicating wastewater contamination. Our study confirms wastewater is indeed impacting surface waters of the Florida Keys with a finding of 69% of the near-shore sites (all sites except the two African reef sites) positive for enteroviruses. While it is accepted that the presence of a pathogen in recreational waters is cause for concern, knowledge of the quantity of pathogen present is necessary for risk assessment. This study is the first to not only detect, but also quantify and identify enteroviral types found in the Florida Keys.

The ability to detect all human pathogenic enteroviruses requires the capability to amplify a conserved region of the enterovirus genome. The ability to identify the different enteroviral types through sequence analysis requires amplification of a region with enough genetic variability to distinguish between the different types. De Leon et al. [30] designed a primer pair (Table 1) that amplified base pair of the 5 0 UTR, the most conserved region of the enteroviral genome. We have obtained 25 enteroviral sequences from Genbank and trimmed them to the 195 bases amplified by De Leon's primer pair. To determine whether there was sufficient genetic information in this 195 base pair fragment each sequence was individually BLAST searched in Genbank for closest relatives. In every case the correct enteroviral type was identified. Therefore, it seems genetic varia-bility in this region is sufficient to enable identification of the different enteroviral types.

A standard curve was needed to quantitate the viral particles. This standard curve was generated by serially diluting and amplifying in triplicate a Poliovirus stock. To determine variability between the replicates, coefficients of variation and standard deviations for the C t 's were calculated. The average coefficient of variation was 0.91 and the average standard deviation was 0.20, both are indicative of low variability. Our findings agree with previous studies [20,31] which found low inter-and intra-assay variability using real-time PCR.

The lowest viral concentration we detected in marine surface waters was 9.3 viral copies (Table 4). Therefore, the lower limit of detection for this methodology extends to at least 9.3 viral particles. This sensitivity is comparable to earlier studies. Becker et al. [32] were able to detect 10 genomes (Anacystis nidulans) and Chen et al. [31] were able to detect as low as 1.8 copies (Salmonella himA gene) using real-time PCR.

When we seeded surface water samples with known quantities of poliovirus, concentrations determined through real-time PCR were within an order of magnitude of the direct count values. The average recovery of poliovirus was estimated to be 53%. At the advice of reviewers, the values presented for enteroviral quantitation were not corrected for this recovery.

It is interesting that positive results were not obtained when samples were concentrated using vortex flow filtration. Station 9A was positive for samples that were not concentrated but negative for vortex flow filtration concentrated samples. It may be that the vortex flow filtration disrupts the enteroviral particles exposing the RNA to RNase degradation. Alternatively, other microbes concentrated in the sample may ingest the viruses. Finally, vortex flow filtration may concentrate PCR inhibitors preventing enteroviral detection.

Sponge tissue taken from a sponge within the Fort Jefferson moat had the highest concentration of viral particles (Table 4). Sponges filter high volumes of water and therefore concentrate viruses and bacteria from the surrounding waters. The detection of enteroviruses in filter feeders such as shellfish is a common occurrence [33][34][35]. Two sites negative for enteroviruses by RT-PCR, African Reef 25 (AR-25) and African Reef 2C (AR-2C) were (Table 4) located approximately 2 nautical miles from Fort Jefferson. Other sites positive for the presence of enteroviruses (Table 4) were near populated areas of Key West and were probably impacted by human wastewater contamination. The sequences we obtained through cloning and sequencing of the RT-PCR amplicons were compared to Genbank sequences using the BLAST program. Three different isolates were identified with at least 99% similarity. The Fort Jefferson Sponge isolate was the only sample identified as Coxsackie A16, while 8 sites contained Coxsackie A9-like viruses and 2 sites were positive for the Poliovirus-like enteroviruses. Viral particles were found in the sponge tissue but not in the surface water most likely because their concentration was below our limit of detection.

A neighbor-joining tree (Fig. 3) grouped isolates in clades with viruses of the same viral type verifying the identity obtained by BLAST searching. Analysis of this tree showed it to be in general agreement with some previously published enterovirus phylogenies [36,37] but in disagreement with others [38,39]. Two major clades were evident, a large clade containing Coxsackie A16, the Coxsackie B viruses, the Echoviruses and Enterovirus 71 and a smaller clade comprised of the Polioviruses, Coxsackie A21, Coxsackie 24 and Enterovirus 70. Huttunen et al. [36] Fig. 3. A neighbor-joining tree derived from an alignment of 196 base pairs of the 5 0 UTR from enteroviral standards and our specimens from the Florida Keys. major capsid proteins. The capsid protein dendrograms found Coxsackie A16 and Enterovirus 70 to be in a third clade. Our tree depicts Coxsackie A21 and Enterovirus as sister-group to the remainder of the Poliovirus/ Coxsackie A virus clade in agreement with Muir et al. [37]. Oberste et al. [39] utilized the 5 0 end of the VP2 gene to derive a phylogenetic tree of all enterovirus serotypes. Their tree produced three major clades and placed [20] shows a log/log relationship between cell culture data and quantitative RT-PCR data Fig. 4. By solving for the X -intercept of the regression equation, one infective unit (MPNCU) corresponds to 55 viral copies detectable by RT-PCR (Fig. 4). Although it has been long known that many more environmental samples are often positive by PCR than cell culture, this is the first attempt to quantify the relationship between the two methods. Although the samples from the Monpoeho et al. [20] were from sludge and not surface waters, it may be that their findings can be used to relate infectivity to a PCR quantified viral abundance. This is an important exercise because quantitative real-time PCR data can be obtained much faster (o1 day) than cell culture results (weeks to months). It is well known that compromised viral particles and nucleic acids will result in detection by PCR but not by cell culture. It may be that a real-time PCR value of 55 particles in a sample is necessary to have the probability of one infectious particle present. To assess health risk of recreational contact with water containing enteroviral particles, the amount of water ingested by any activity times the concentration of infectious particles needs to be known. If swimmers ingest an average of 30-50 ml of water [40] then real-time PCR concentrations of enteroviruses should not exceed 1.10-1.83 PCR particles/ml, assuming that an infection can result from one ''viable'' (cell culture positive) viral particle. All of our positive samples in the Keys exceeded these concentrations. Other contact activities (jet-skiing, windsurfing, kayaking, etc.) probably result in less water ingestion and a lower risk and may be appropriate for canals and waterways similar to the ones tested in this study. Finally, sludge samples may be recalcitrant to inactivation compared to surface waters, where UV light and temperature may inactivate infectious viral particles at a faster rate. Sludge samples may also be more inhibitory to cell culture (or PCR) than surface waters, and a direct comparison of cell culture and PCR should be made. One such study in Sarasota, Florida found a high fidelity between PCR and cell culture data (88% of the PCR positive samples were also positive by cell culture; [41]).

One caveat concerning this study should be addressed. The finding of isolates identical to our positive control may have been from a contamination event in the laboratory. However, samples found to be negative for enteroviruses were also run side by side with positive samples and negative controls run with every RT-PCR set were consistently negative. An alternate explanation may be that our positive control (Polio Sabin 1) was identical in the 5 0 UTR to that used in immunizations, and therefore correctly detected such viruses shed into the water. Only amplification and sequencing of other portions of the genomes from the positive samples would verify or negate this hypothesis.

Several goals of this on going research have been achieved. A rapid, specific, sensitive, cost efficient and reproducible method has been developed to detect and quantitate enterovirus RNA in marine waters. This research demonstrates the utility of real-time RT-PCR for monitoring environmental waters. Further studies are underway to refine this method for the rapid detection, quantitation and identification of other pathogenic viruses in environmental waters.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 1A-C) in August of 1997. Two sites in the Dry Tortugas, African Reef 2C (AR-2C) and African Reef 25 (AR-25) were located approximately 2 nautical miles west of Fort Jefferson. Surface water from a suspected sewage outfall site was collected by grab sample in an area of turbid water southeast of Key West. In addition to water samples, approximately 3.2 g of sponge tissue was collected

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: (A) Map of southwest Florida. (B) Map of Key West showing sampling sites. (C) Map of Fort Jefferson, Dry Tortugas showing sampling sites.

Primers and probe for one-step real-time RT-PCR Upstream 5 0 -GGCCCCTGAATGCGGCTAAT-3 0 192 base pair 5 0 untranslated region Downstream 5 0 -CACCGGATGGCCAATCCAA-3 0 Probe 5 0 -CGGACACCCAAAGTAGTCGGTTCCG-3 0

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Nine of the sites or 60% were positive by RT-PCR for the presence of enteroviruses. None of the membrex concentrated samples resulted in a positive amplification. The concentrations of enteroviral particles detected ranged from 9.3/ml to 83/g of sponge tissue. The largest concentration, 83 particles, was detected in the sponge tissue. Three strains of waterborne enteroviruses isolated from the Florida Keys were identified as Coxsackie A9, Coxsackie A16, and Poliovirus Sabin type 1 through Poliovirus standard curve. Dilutions of a Poliovirus Sabin type 1 stock were made and logs of the counts were regressed against corresponding threshold cycles.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: A graphic comparison of quantitative RT-PCR results with quantitative cell culture results of artificially seeded sludge samples (adapted from[20]).
